in early benchmarks performed by tech sites such as anandtech and pcmag, the s4 pro, despite being clocked at the same 1.5ghz, smokes every competitor except the ipad 3′s a5x. in graphics benchmarks, the new adreno 320 gpu is twice as fast as its predecessor, the adreno 225 (found in the s4 plus). the adreno 320 still loses out to the a5xs quad-core powervr sgx 543mp4 in most benchmarks, but it beats tegra 3 and exynos 4 (mali 400) comfortably. the dual-core s4 was already giving the quad-core tegra 3 and samsung exynos 4 chips a run for their money and now, with four cores and the adreno 320 gpu, nvidia and samsung have been left in the dust. for the most part, this is entirely down to the fact that qualcomms snapdragon s4 uses the cortex-a15-esque krait core, which is miles ahead of the cortex-a9 core used by every other arm smartphone soc on the market. so, when apple a5x-processor matches the quad-core snapdragon s4, now the a6 with arm cortex a15 architecture will leave everything else in the dust.

processor: why would you care the number of cores, architecture, etc if it just works with no lag? i hope you don't buy a phone just to run benchmarks. ram: the way ios implements multitasking by suspending apps, not as much ram is required. android offers multitasking with the apps actually running, so more ram. so why it all depends on the os. (ie, why microsoft windows requires much higher spec than linux? they're just different) size: if you just want it big, why do you think galaxy note is too big? i do like being able to do things single-handedly. if size is everything, don't use a phone, use a galaxy tab. screen: i hope you're not buying a phone just to stare at the screen for pixels. they're all good. design: everybody knows it's really subjective here . no phone is really ugly, just to you, perhaps. apps: this one apple does win. even the same apps are better designed for ios than android. openess: this one android wins. why jail the phone? if i want to save files to my device, just let me do so. i love android this way. again, the point is, don't defend your phone with your life before trying the others. every phone has goods and bads. i don't believe iphone or sg3 is the best on the planet. if you think otherwise, you're jailed by yourself and need to be jail broken. so, be open and be nice.

i used to be a symbian fan (since n95). then the iphone came out. nokia fanboys at the time were reluctant to give the iphone a try, but kept saying that it sucked. but the moment i tried one, i couldn't believe how i've lived in denial. then i became an apple fanboy. at the time with my iphone 4, galaxy s2 came about. i gave it a try and, well, there were goods and bads. the apps on android just don't look as good as on the iphone. seems like developers develop the ios version ahead of android. but the good, i can use my s2 the way i like it, especially with saving files and using it as a usb mass storage device. different browsers that actually behave like different browsers. what i don't like is how background in is implemented here. i have to keep watching out what's eating my battery. and rouge apps could be running without me knowing. iphone background in is not real but i actually like it because apps can be truly suspended. now iphone 5 comes along. i think i'll give it a try. my point is, for apple fanboys, iphone 5 does lack a bit of customizability, android gives you much more freedom. but if you like stock everything then what can we do. for android fanboys, if you haven't tried an iphone, you really should, you'll be surprised. if you have, you'll understand when i said that both have some shortcomings. be open, and be nice.

gsma's first impressions of the new iphone 5.. and i qoute "on the negative side, the iphone 5 screen is only 4 inches big, and not only this, but only height was added, which, for instance, would bring no real benefit in most games and would help web browsing only in landscape mode. the camera is mostly the same as on the 4s, and lte connectivity in europe is still as scarce as water in the sahara to be really worth it. finally, the new sleeker connectivity jack renders all previous docking accessories obsolete and yet, provides no intercompatibility with the all-reigning microusb. not to mention the new nano sim card, which would be a major pain in the butt, if youve got an unlocked iphone and youd like to swap sims frequently. honestly, im already tired of hearing apples stale remarks how the new iphone or the new ipod was apples best thing so far. what i wanted to see today on stage was pure innovation, something that would again open new doors and make other manufacturers lose their breath in trying to catch up. instead, what i got was a predictable phone with unexciting specs; a phone that i would hardly call cutting edge, top-of-the-line, and all those labels that usually go hand in hand with apples latest. after all, the iphone has always been the most expensive sim-free smartphone on the market. sure, people will probably continue to buy it in millions, since once its out, it would be the most sensible buy, if you are after an iphone. but i still have that bad taste in my mouth. the iphone 5 failed to meet my expectations. i didnt have a feature wishlist, except perhaps a seriously bigger screen. but most of all, i expected to be surprised. well, none of these two things happened. and i wonder, whos to blame? is it me, or is it apple thats changing into a conservative phone maker, who likes to play it safe like nokia used to, before it became clear its not getting them anywhere. im more than sure that somebody in south korea is having a big party right now. more than anything, it feels like this years iphone is apple skipping a turn a second year in a row all the while android and windows phones have been seriously upping their game".... ouch

i was there at the iphone 5 releasing ceremony yesterday. and by god i was soo excited that i hadn't been this excited for sooooo long! and the excitement breaks down into this huge disappointment when i saw the iphone. at least this is not what i had expected. yes the screens nice, the phone looks well built but it misses that charm. that charm that the iphone 4 had. and the iphone 4 was a real revolution in the industry and there was this huge hope, all of the journalists that this would too change the world of smartphone, but it didn't. doesn't look like it moved it an inch. i had seen the iphone 5 much before its release and by god i never thought that those would even resemble the iphone. but it did. the r&d didn't try this time. the phones just the same when it comes to processing power, looks, camera and etc. just that it has a tad bigger screen and the back is two toned. except that. the phones the same. update your 4s to ios 6 and you have the iphone 5. the only difference it's got is lte on board. and don't expect it to have a "quad-core" with supercharges on board. as there is no quad-core processor that supports lte. so most probably a dual-core krait with adreno 225 on ye hardware side. not a bad choice. but not what i expected. really disappointed with this one. i wish steve jobs was still with us. he revolutionized the industry with his innovations. don't think tim is doing the same. well i would prefer the nokia lumia 920/820 or even the samsung galaxy s3 over this phone. i would tell you people to do the same. hopefully apple stops playing safe. miss you steve.

lumia 920 vs galaxy s3 vs iphone 5 call quality - lumia, 99% sure with nokia phones signal reception - lumia, same as above build quality - lumia design - lumia/iphone 5 camera - lumia, pureview camera with optical image stabilization (floating lens) and best for low light shots. both iphone 5 and galaxy s3 use software image stabilization instead of hardware like on the lumia. screen - lumia, puremotion hd+ is the most fluid (2.5x faster than current screen), the brightest, and the best for viewing outdoor with clearblack polarizer layer technology. lumia 920 is the first with synatics advanced touchscreen that works with gloves, keys, fingernails, etc... audio recording - lumia, haac rich recording with 3 distortion free high amplitude microphones. music quality through headphone jack - leaning toward galaxy s3 because it has the wolfson audio chip, though the lumia has dolby digital plus headphone enhancement. iphones have great audio quality with iphone 4/4s.

apple still first company to use a15 in a chip others failed.. with the launch of iphone 5 apple has become the first mobile company to launch the arms cortex a15 cpu into the market. a very skilled person when it comes to semiconductors, anand lal shimpi of anandtech, also gave his comments on the powerful cpu. he said, based on the performance gains, apples history of soc naming and some other stuff weve heard recently, it looks like apple has integrated two arm cortex a15 cores on samsungs 32nm lp hk+mg process. he further said that it is a very large jump for apple while beating samsung and texas instruments (ti) at the same time. apart from ti and samsung, nvidia and broadcom was also in league to release a15s but have failed. all the four companies mentioned above had made a statement to release a15s in exynos 5250 for samsung, tegra 4 (code-named wayne) for nvidia, a system-on-chip by broadcom, tis omap5 application processor but apple did it first. arms two cortex-a15 cores along with two mail gpu cores are expected to be present in samsungs exynos 5. source,

the iphone is a device made for people that want a quality product. galaxy s3 might be better in some aspects, but it's made of plastic. hold an iphone, you'll see the quality of the product as you touch it, touch an s3 and you will feel like breaking it if you sqeeze it too tight. also, the camera on the iphone beats everything i've ever put my hands on. from the moment 3gs came out and sony erricson didn't came with a better product with a better camera (imho they were the only competition apple had when it came to cameras). iphone lover or not, i respect a good quality product. yes, you are limited, you may not find youtube videos as you would on an s3 because they want you to buy it from itunes, they don't allow you to exchange information via bluetooth and they want you to buy all their products on applestore (if you're not jailbroken like me). but i would still choose it over an s3. the only thing i missed with the previous iphones is that they were lacking behind with the display size. and be honest, you can't say that apple couldn't have made a bigger display 3 years ago. the only reason for keeping the size of the display smaller is because steve jobs considered that a mobile phone should have some dimension limits, and i think that if he would still be alive now, he would have modified the 4s to have a bigger display without making the phone bigger. i had a galaxy nexus for 1 week. i could not wear tight jeans, and generally i could take it out of my pocket if i wasn't standing up. i don't want to mention if i had a galaxy note how would that be. retina display is an extaordinary feature that apple fist came up with. the quality and volume of the iphone is only compared with an ipod or another apple product, and i heard a lot of phones and devices. ios is a very friendly os. the map was better than most smartphones even before, i am very curious how this one will be. you can hate as much as you want. i consider this product being something i will enjoy and not feel sorry if i buy. my 2 cents

yeah after the shocking launch of iphone 5 which was a crap but if these 5 things that could have made the iphone 5 an even better smartphone 1,expandable memory :sure, apple offers the iphone 5 with different amounts of storage space, up to 64gb, but it's way cheaper, and sometimes even more practical to just use a microsd card, which you can easily take out and insert into another device. 2,more informative, dynamic homescreen :wouldn't it be cool if the iphone 5's homescreen could show a bit more information? how about getting real-time updates on the weather, or short incoming message previews, or your next calendar events? most of these things already appear on the lockscreen, but they disappear once you unlock your handset. plus, it would be undeniably great if all that info is present right on the homescreen as well. oh well, maybe in a future ios release... 3, nfc :nfc is not included in the iphone 5, which means we're in for another painful year for mobile payments and other nfc applications. probably waiting until the time is right, apple will not give the thumbs up to nfc for at least another 12 months. 4,wireless charging :there can be no argument here, wireless charging is a great convenience. just place your iphone on the neatly-designed charging pad and it's all set - no need to connect cables or anything like that. it just works! well, not really, because apple is yet to adopt such technology. 5,water- and dust-resistant coating :you've probably heard of these new water- and dust-proof coatings. they make your handset that much more resistant to the elements, without altering the its gorgeous looks one bit. sadly, even though the iphone 5 is one incredibly well-designed and constructed device, it still doesn't have such a coating, meaning you'll still have to handle it with extreme care.

even gsma are disappointed and i quote "on the negative side, the iphone 5 screen is only 4 inches big, and not only this, but only height was added, which, for instance, would bring no real benefit in most games and would help web browsing only in landscape mode. the camera is mostly the same as on the 4s, and lte connectivity in europe is still as scarce as water in the sahara to be really worth it. finally, the new sleeker connectivity jack renders all previous docking accessories obsolete and yet, provides no intercompatibility with the all-reigning microusb. not to mention the new nano sim card, which would be a major pain in the butt, if youve got an unlocked iphone and youd like to swap sims frequently. honestly, im already tired of hearing apples stale remarks how the new iphone or the new ipod was apples best thing so far. what i wanted to see today on stage was pure innovation, something that would again open new doors and make other manufacturers lose their breath in trying to catch up. instead, what i got was a predictable phone with unexciting specs; a phone that i would hardly call cutting edge, top-of-the-line, and all those labels that usually go hand in hand with apples latest. after all, the iphone has always been the most expensive sim-free smartphone on the market. "

before buying this istone5,please know what a galaxy note 2 can do - the new galaxy note recognizes when users remove its stylus. when you pull out the so-called s pen, the device will switch to a customized home screen that highlights stylus-focused applications. the device also recognizes if you shut it off without replacing the stylus; in such cases, it will remind you to do so. -because of their small screens, smartphones rarely place applications or documents in windows like you would see on a desktop computer. instead, pages and programs generally run full-screen. but the galaxy note 2 is trying to bring back windowed applications -the new version has a 5.5-inch screen, which is slightly bigger than the originals 5.3-inch display. thanks to the extra pixels, the display has a 16:9 ratio, meaning that when you watch high-definition movies on it, you wont see any black borders. -the new device did have some cool photography features. its got a built-in burst mode that will take up to 20 shots at once. it also has a group-photo feature that will allow you to take a picture of a group of people, will instantly recognize the faces of people in the photo and allows you to choose from several different selections to find the best image of each persons face. the facial recognition was spotty it didnt recognize peoples faces unless they were looking close to directly at the camera and the feature took several seconds to take and process the photo. hope u can realise how much samsung is trying to give more innovative and user friendly devices.
